```
Troubleshooting: If the build failed due to an out-of-memory error, you
may be able to fix it by disabling the `dev_build` and/or `minimize` options.

If you are building via the `jupyter lab build` command, you can disable
these options like so:

jupyter lab build --dev-build=False --minimize=False

You can also disable these options for all JupyterLab builds by adding these
lines to a Jupyter config file named `jupyter_config.py`:

c.LabBuildApp.minimize = False
c.LabBuildApp.dev_build = False

If you don't already have a `jupyter_config.py` file, you can create one by
adding a blank file of that name to any of the Jupyter config directories.
The config directories can be listed by running:

jupyter --paths

Explanation:

- `dev-build`: This option controls whether a `dev` or a more streamlined
`production` build is used. This option will default to `False` (ie the
`production` build) for most users. However, if you have any labextensions
installed from local files, this option will instead default to `True`.
Explicitly setting `dev-build` to `False` will ensure that the `production`
build is used in all circumstances.

- `minimize`: This option controls whether your JS bundle is minified
during the Webpack build, which helps to improve JupyterLab's overall
performance. However, the minifier plugin used by Webpack is very memory
intensive, so turning it off may help the build finish successfully in
low-memory environments.
```

items.title: Compiling extensions without source map files
items.body:
### Problem

JLab 3.0 extensions are built with .map files, even in production mode, which take a huge amount of space.

### Proposed Solution

We should make it possible (and possibly recommended/default) to build the new extensions without .map files.

For example, for the ipywidgets jupyterlab manager, the static folder went from 2240K (with source maps) to 488K (without source maps).

items.title: Drag from file browser to dock panel no longer works
items.body: In previous versions of JupyterLab, you could drag a file from the file browser to the dock panel and pick where the file would be opened. This no longer works in master. That might have been a deliberate decision, but want to make sure before we release 3.0

items.title: Completion renderer cannot be changed
maximum recursion depth exceeded in comparison

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
I am new to this whole world and am in a Python class. I entered in some code and keep getting the error 'RecursionError: maximum recursion depth exceeded in comparison'.
I saved this script as permute.py in Jupyter Lab.
```python
def permute1(seq):
    if not seq:
        retrn [seq]
    else:
        res=[]
        for i in range(len(seq)):
            rest=seq[:i]+seq[i:+1:]
            for x in permute1(rest):
                res.append(seq[i:i+1]+x)
            return res
```
Opened a new notebook an imported it
```python
from permute import permute1
permute1('abc')
```
clicked run then the error popped up. I've even tried importing sys and using the sys.setrecursionlimit(10**6) and the kernel will crash and restart with out running the code.

Any help would be greatly appreciated. Thank you.

I should note that I have gotten this code to work in a Python Command Prompt just not in Jupyter.

items.title: JupyterLab application assets not found in <directory> (Docker)
items.body:
Hi I'm having some trouble with a JupyterLab docker image. This is the docker image: [DockerHub](https://hub.docker.com/repository/docker/bgameiro/arch-jupyterlab/), [Dockerfile on GitHub](https://github.com/BGameiro2000/dockerfile/blob/master/arch-jupyterlab/Dockerfile) Dockerfile: (because I might change the image to try to solve the problem so use the dockerfile instead) 
# Use archlinux:latest as parent image
FROM archlinux:latest

# Set maintainer
LABEL maintainer='BGameiro '

# Update mirrors and packages. Install jupyterlab
RUN pacman --noconfirm -Syyu jupyterlab

# Build the lab
RUN jupyter lab build --minimize=False

# Expose port and path
EXPOSE 8888
VOLUME /appdata

# Add packages and functionalities
# ENV pkgs=PACKAGES
# CMD pacman --noconfirm -S 

# Run JupyterLab
CMD cp -R -n /usr/share/jupyter/* /appdata && jupyter lab --ip=* --port=8888 --no-browser --notebook-dir=/opt/app/data --allow-root --app-dir=/appdata || jupyter lab --ip=* --port=8888 --no-browser --notebook-dir=/opt/app/data --allow-root --app-dir=/appdata --generate-config
## Description After accessing the webui the message `JupyterLab application assets not found in "/appdata" ` appears. The docker image is created from the official Archlinux image where JupyterLab is installed and, for good measure, is built again with `jupyter lab build`. The files are then copied to another directory (`cp -R -n /usr/share/jupyter/* /appdata`) that is mounted as a volume. I use this command: `jupyter lab --ip=* --port=8888 --no-browser --notebook-dir=/opt/app/data --allow-root --app-dir=/appdata` Both directories (`/appdata` and `/usr/share/jupyter`) have the same content once the docker container is running and both have the following subdirectories: - `kernels` - `lab` - `extensions` - `imports.css` - `schemas` - `settings` - `staging` - `static` - `themes` - `nbextensions` ## Reproduce The docker image (`bgameiro/arch-jupyterlab:latest`) can be used to reproduce. ## Context I created the image to bring JupyterLab to Unraid, the Unraid repo can be found [here](https://github.com/BGameiro2000/unraid-ca/blob/master/jupyterlab/jupyterlab.xml).

items.title: set_next_input delayed execution when run within widget on_click function

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
# Description

When running a set_next_input it works find run from a cell, but if you do it in a function call on a button widget on_click, it only works after the next cell you run. 

## Reproduce
This  in a cell will insert a cell bellow with the print statement in it

```from IPython.display import display
from ipywidgets import widgets
ipy = get_ipython()
ipy.set_next_input("print('No Button')")
```

This however, running this:
```
from IPython.display import display
from ipywidgets import widgets
ipy = get_ipython()
def button_click(b):
    ipy.set_next_input("print('In Button')")
    
mybutton = widgets.Button(description="Press")
mybutton.on_click(button_click)
display(widgets.VBox([mybutton]))
```
and pressing the button will do nothing, until you next your run cell. For example, if you put
```
print("")
```
in another cell, it will show the 
```
print('In Button")
```
From the previous run. 

## Expected behavior

When you press the button, it should insert a cell, and fill it with the code requested. 

## Context


- Operating System and version: Running on MacOS using Conda
- Browser and version: Chrome 84.0.4147.105 
- JupyterLab version: 2.1.4

items.title: Unable to submit `body: FormData` in `ServerConnection.makeRequest()`
items.body:
When I submit `body: FormData` to `ServerConnection.makeRequest()` `Content-Type` header (`multipart/form-data ...`) gets overridden with `application/json`. According to the [code](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/master/packages/services/src/serverconnection.ts#L298), this happens when `Request#bodyUsed` is `false`. I believe that in my case `bodyUsed` should be `true`, but it is not:

```
form_data = new FormData()
form_data.append('key', 'value')
new Request('http://example.com', {body: form_data, method: 'POST'}).bodyUsed
// false
```

I also tried to get `bodyUsed` with some other body type (e.g. string), but have failed:

```
new Request('http://example.com', {body: 'key=value', method: 'POST'}).bodyUsed
// false
```

I have tried Safari 13.1.2 (15609.3.5.1.3), Yandex 20.8.0.893 and Firefox 79.0.

What should this code work like?
I believe that the check should be changed from `!request.bodyUsed` to `!request.headers.has('Content-Type')`.

items.title: No copy from one notebook to another => Can't use Matplotlib, Python, or Sympy

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
Maple was insufficient for my project; Mathematica was insufficient, Maxima was insufficient; Sympy was my last hope, but can't afford to even start with it, because, what if a situation came up where I had to copy a range of cells from one notebook to another? Python ecosystem doesn't do that.

Returned Maple because of the user interface. Can't use Maxima because, it's undocumented and buggy. Quit Mathematica out of frustration with bugs and poor documentation. Trying to use CAS in a notebook truly has been the worst four-year phase of my career, intellectual journey, and life. Four years of unstimulating drudgery, unpaid and with no results.

Given that I could copy from document to document in 1980, I move Jupyterlab version be called alpha until that functionality is added.

items.title: Upgrade helper for extensions
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Thanks for thinking of a way to improve JupyterLab. If this solves a problem for you, then it probably solves that problem for lots of people! So the whole community will benefit from this request.


Before creating a new feature request please search the issues for relevant feature requests.
-->

### Problem
It should be easy for extension authors to upgrade their extensions with support for JupyterLab 3.0.

<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of what problem this feature will solve. For example:

* I'm always frustrated when [...] because [...]
* I would like it if [...] happened when I [...] because [...]
-->

### Proposed Solution
Create a script that extension authors can run that will generate the Python package infrastructure and update `package.json` with support for dynamic extensions.   For extensions that already have a `setup.py`, we update their `package.json` and offer a note (and link to example) for updating their `setup.py` (and `pyproject.toml`).

items.title: Add watch handling for non-symlinked dynamic extensions
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Thanks for thinking of a way to improve JupyterLab. If this solves a problem for you, then it probably solves that problem for lots of people! So the whole community will benefit from this request.


Before creating a new feature request please search the issues for relevant feature requests.
-->

### Problem
Extensions that are installed with `labextension develop` without a symlink currently do not support `watch` mode.

<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of what problem this feature will solve. For example:

* I'm always frustrated when [...] because [...]
* I would like it if [...] happened when I [...] because [...]
-->

### Proposed Solution
- When we call `labextension watch`, check for a `symlink` to the watched directory.   If none exists, check for a `labextensions` directory.  If none exists, bail.  If there is a `labextensions` directory, set up file system watchers to copy changes to that location from the `src` directory of the extension in addition to running the local `watch` command.

items.title: Make settings overrides a trait
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Thanks for thinking of a way to improve JupyterLab. If this solves a problem for you, then it probably solves that problem for lots of people! So the whole community will benefit from this request.


Before creating a new feature request please search the issues for relevant feature requests.
-->

### Problem
Right now, setting overrides are handled in `share/lab/settings/overrides.json`.  For administered applications, the user has no way to provide user or environment-level overrides.

<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of what problem this feature will solve. For example:

* I'm always frustrated when [...] because [...]
* I would like it if [...] happened when I [...] because [...]
-->

### Proposed Solution
- Add config for `overrides` using our [`ConfigManager`](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/66cde329b50a975cc1117a2f4e6bc30eaa106c6f/jupyterlab/commands.py#L301) (will need to move to `jupyterlab_server`)
- Use this config manager in [`_get_overrides](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab_server/blob/edf4a17d72a8fe7e13f5dc9761e425d8929023e2/jupyterlab_server/settings_handler.py#L257) - layer these traits on top of `overrides.json` values.
- Update [`docs`](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/869ed91e60f08e7e1c6787da27ec87255ced00bf/docs/source/user/extensions.rst#settings)
<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of a way to accomplish what you want. For example:

* Add an option so that when [...]  [...] will happen
 -->

items.title: Send wait screen before loading extensions javascript

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
### Problem

Right now when Jupyterlab starts up it loads an extension file which could be several megabytes.  In this time browser has no load screen and the system seems dead for a minute.  This only happens on the first run as the extension file is cached afterwards.

### Proposed Solution

This can be fixed by loading and displaying the wait screen first, and then loading in the extension file rather than waiting for the extensions javascript file to load.

### Additional context

This will  greatly improve usability as a lot of extensions now have large javascript files that require a large amount of time to load.

items.title: Separate out a new builder package
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Thanks for thinking of a way to improve JupyterLab. If this solves a problem for you, then it probably solves that problem for lots of people! So the whole community will benefit from this request.


Before creating a new feature request please search the issues for relevant feature requests.
-->

### Problem
We are starting to add a lot of dependencies to `buildutils` that aren't needed for simple utilities like `update:dependency`.  
<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of what problem this feature will solve. For example:

* I'm always frustrated when [...] because [...]
* I would like it if [...] happened when I [...] because [...]
-->

### Proposed Solution
Create a new top-level `builder` package (`@jupyterlab/builder`) that has the `webpack` config and the `build-extension` script.
 
<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of a way to accomplish what you want. For example:

* Add an option so that when [...]  [...] will happen
 -->

### Additional context
Also need to move the `source-map-loader` and `html-loader` out of this package and back into `dev_mode`.

<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. You can also include links to examples of other programs that have something similar to your request. For example:

* Another project [...] solved this by [...]
-->

items.title: Allow greater access to some of the the properties and methods of class DSVModel.
items.body:
Hi, my name is Logan McNichols. I am an intern for Jupyter Cal Poly. I am working on a tabular data editor powered by the `DataGrid` along with @kgoo124 and @ryuntalan.

### Problem

The `DSVModel` provide a great foundation for our `EditorModel` class designed to edit csv data. However, the methods and properties of the `DSVModel` that we need are currently not accessible outside the class. This means that we are currently relying on a duplicate package with a few slight modifications.

### Proposed Solution

We request that the following methods of the `DSVModel` be made `public`:
- `_getOffsetIndex`
- `_parseAsync`

And that getters be provided for the following properties of the `DSVModel`:
- `_data`
- `_initialRows`
- `_header`
- `_delimiter`
- `_rowDelimiter`
- `_doneParsing`

And that setters be provided for the following properties of the `DSVModel`:
- `_data` (Allows us to serialize and save the modified csv file)
- `_initialRows` (By setting this to be the `rowCount` temporarily, we can get `parseAsync` to run synchronously)
- `_header` (Allows us to customize the `DataGrid` header (e.g. have default letter headers like excel or google sheets).

items.title: Examples test pass only because they are in the jlab source tree
items.body:
Right now, there are some issues with the examples building when they are copied outside of the jlab source tree because they don't specify all their dependencies, etc. Other issues like #8843 could have been caught as well if they were copied outside of the source tree before testing.

I think we ought to test examples by:

- copying the example outside of the jlab repo
- linking the example dependencies back to the jlab repo packages (so we are testing against the current state of the repo)
- *then* building the example and running it

items.title: Make module federation remoteEntry.js use hashes
items.body:
Let's enable hashes for remoteEntry.js files so that browser won't cache these files across extension upgrades.

- [x] Change https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/b8a145acd9ad599d5505384b4c2a39495cb9850c/buildutils/src/webpack.config.ext.ts#L157 to be something like `remoteEntry.[chunkhash].js`, I think should do it
- [x] Store this path somewhere in generated extension metadata?
- [x] Change the server to include the loading path in the pageconfig extension metadata again (which we recently removed because it was redundant).

items.title: Directly opening a path to a notebook fails (3.0.0a10)
items.body:
## Description Opening a URL to a notebook such as http://localhost:8888/lab/tree/example.ipynb fails in JupyterLab version: 3.0.0a10 ## Reproduce ``` conda create -n lab3 python==3.8 pip conda activate lab3 pip install jupyterlab==3.0.0a10 jupyter-lab --debug --LabApp.token= --port=8888 ``` 1. Start JupyterLab, e.g. http://localhost:8888/lab 2. Open a notebook in JupyterLab, e.g. `example.ipynb` 3. The notebook will be opened, and the browser location bar changes to http://localhost:8888/lab/tree/example.ipynb 4. Refresh the page (e.g. Ctrl-R in Firefox), or go to http://localhost:8888/lab/tree/example.ipynb. Page becomes blank ## Expected behavior Notebook should reload. ## Context - Operating System and version: Linux Fedora 32 - Browser and version: Firefox 79.0 (64-bit) - JupyterLab version: 3.0.0a10 Examining the browser dev-tools shows that http://localhost:8888/lab/tree/static/lab/main.7f9ff316a540929d02e8.js is loaded as HTML instead of Javascript: ``` JupyterLab ``` It looks like that's a generic page, and the correct Javascript location is http://localhost:8888/static/lab/main.7f9ff316a540929d02e8.js

items.title: Extension remoteEntry.js has a hardcoded webpack public path
items.body:
Right now we are hardcoding the webpack public path when compiling extensions: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/7d1e17381d3ed61c23c189822810e8b4918d57ba/buildutils/src/webpack.config.ext.ts#L132

We should be setting this at runtime from the page config options.

See also https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/10352#issuecomment-673165799

items.title: Matplotlib figures are not redrawn in the cell in which they are created
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->

Using an interactive figure's `canvas.draw()` method does not update the figure if it was created in the same cell as the draw call.

Figure created in the same cell:
![Same cell](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1909532/90080052-d39ae300-dcc6-11ea-90cb-1bf3429548c6.gif)

Figure created in another cell:
![different cell](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1909532/90080105-02b15480-dcc7-11ea-965d-14114cb27c96.gif)


## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

1. Open a new notebook in JupyterLab
2. Insert the following code:
````
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import time

%matplotlib widget

fig = plt.figure()

for i in range(5):
    x = list(range(i+2))
    xx = [x**2 for x in x]
    plt.clf()
    plt.plot(x, xx)
    fig.canvas.draw()
    
    time.sleep(1)
````
3. Run the cell and observe that the plot does not show until the loop has exited.

Optional:
1. Switch to classic notebook
2. Change widget to notebook
3. Run cell and observe plot updates during the loop

This can be reproduced using the [scipy notebook docker stack](https://jupyter-docker-stacks.readthedocs.io/en/latest/using/selecting.html#jupyter-scipy-notebook).

<!--Describe how you diagnosed the issue. See the guidelines at
 https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html -->

## Expected behavior

<!--Describe what you expected to happen-->

Plot updates in the loop

## Context

<!--Complete the following for context, and add any other relevant context-->

- Operating System and version: Windows 10 (Running JupyterLab in Docker)
- Browser and version: Chrome Version 84.0.4147.125
- JupyterLab version: 2.1.5

items.title: Phosphor shim is not fully functional
items.body:
The phosphor [shim](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/master/buildutils/src/webpack.config.base.ts#L66) relies on a local `@lumino` package being installed.   We probably need some more advanced logic to install `lumino` if we detect that `@phosphor` packages are installed.

cc @jasongrout

items.title: Opening Terminal or Refreshing Terminal shows auth token transmitted within URL
items.body:
### Problem

* When the terminal is opened or refreshed in jupyterlab inspecting the flow on the browser reveals that the auth token is passed within URL as opposed to headers of the request when switching protocols to websocket. This poses security risk as the attacker who can view URL parameters can retrieve this token that can allow access to jupyter notebooks.

### Proposed Solution

* Pass auth token in request headers as opposed to concatenating with URL.

### Additional context
*  Environment Details - Jupyterhub running on Amazon EKS

Amazon EKS - `v1.16.8/v1.15.11 ( tested on both versions )`
Spawner details - `Kubespawner v0.12.1.dev0`
```
5cd193ad30c6:~$ jupyter-lab --version
2.0.1
5cd193ad30c6:~$ jupyterhub --version
1.1.0
5cd193ad30c6:~$ jupyter-notebook --version
6.0.3
```
**Logs**

```
[I 2020-08-11 17:51:50.395 SingleUserNotebookApp log:174] 200 POST /hub/user/john_doe/api/terminals?1597168310266 (john_doe@10.56.1.20) 49.73ms
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:50.509 SingleUserNotebookApp auth:871] Allowing whitelisted Hub user john_doe
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:50.509 SingleUserNotebookApp auth:744] Setting oauth cookie for 10.56.1.20: jupyterhub-user-john_doe, {'path': '/hub/user/john_doe/', 'httponly': True, 'secure': True}
[I 2020-08-11 17:51:50.511 SingleUserNotebookApp log:174] 200 GET /hub/user/john_doe/api/terminals?1597168310441 (john_doe@10.56.1.20) 2.72ms
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:50.924 SingleUserNotebookApp auth:871] Allowing whitelisted Hub user john_doe
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:50.924 SingleUserNotebookApp auth:744] Setting oauth cookie for 10.56.1.20: jupyterhub-user-john_doe, {'path': '/hub/user/john_doe/', 'httponly': True}
[I 2020-08-11 17:51:50.926 SingleUserNotebookApp log:174] 101 GET /hub/user/john_doe/terminals/websocket/2?token=[secret] (john_doe@10.56.1.20) 2.34ms
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:50.926 SingleUserNotebookApp zmqhandlers:157] Opening websocket /hub/user/john_doe/terminals/websocket/2
TermSocket.open: 2
TermSocket.open: Opened 2
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:51.208 SingleUserNotebookApp auth:871] Allowing whitelisted Hub user john_doe
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:51.208 SingleUserNotebookApp auth:744] Setting oauth cookie for 10.56.1.20: jupyterhub-user-john_doe, {'path': '/hub/user/john_doe/', 'httponly': True, 'secure': True}
[I 2020-08-11 17:51:51.213 SingleUserNotebookApp log:174] 204 PUT /hub/user/john_doe/lab/api/workspaces/lab?1597168311142 (john_doe@10.56.1.20) 5.85ms
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:51.962 SingleUserNotebookApp auth:871] Allowing whitelisted Hub user john_doe
[D 2020-08-11 17:51:51.962 SingleUserNotebookApp auth:744] Setting oauth cookie for 10.56.1.20: jupyterhub-user-john_doe, {'path': '/hub/user/john_doe/', 'httponly': True, 'secure': True}
```

**Steps to reproduce** 
1. Once the user pod spawns, open browser inspect window 
2. Open launcher > click on terminal
3. You will see `wss://xyz.com/hub/user/john_doe/terminals/websocket/1?token=xxxxxxxxxxxxxx` in the request URL.
Anyone having access to the above URL can get into that user's environment using `https://xyz.com/hub/user/john_doe/?token=xxxxxxxxxxxxxx`



Would be great to know if there is a way to fix this issue.
    
Thanks.

items.title: App version is not properly handled
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description
After the switch to `jupyter_server`, the `app_version` is not properly handled.  A workaround is to force a call to `self.app_version = self._default_app_version()`, which I've done temporarily in #8810 

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->

## Reproduce
- `pip install jupyterlab==3.0.0a8`
- `jupyter lab`
- Go to `Help -> About` and look at the version

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

<!--Describe how you diagnosed the issue. See the guidelines at
 https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html -->

## Expected behavior
Shows the version as `3.0.0a8`
<!--Describe what you expected to happen-->

items.title: Punctuation invisible in dark mode on jlab 3
items.body:
## Description Punctuation is not receiving styling in order to contrast with dark mode in jupyterlab 3 ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10111092/89678909-03f51280-d8be-11ea-93db-7268c33ba004.png) ## Reproduce - Run master branch in dev-mode or `pip install jupyterlab==3.0.0a6` - settings > Dark Mode - Type some punctuation e.g: `(.,:;{}[])` - none of it is styled. ## Expected behavior These characters have higher contrast with the background. In jlab=2 they are white: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10111092/89678724-b5e00f00-d8bd-11ea-9077-877bdd189a09.png) ## Context - Operating System and version: Ubuntu 20.04 - Browser and version: Firefox 78 - JupyterLab version: 3.0.0a6 (also on master)

items.title: [DISCUSS] Benchmarks in own repo?
items.body:
We have now a `benchmark` folder. The goal is to bring more test coverage, but maybe also store  benchmark results.

We could have also different release cycles than the other jlab core packages (sometimes, we would want to release benchmark faster that other packages).

We also want to run the benchmark on various branches/tags in a automated way.

An option to bring more flexibility (in terms of csv, png... results content storage, release...) and to avoid noise on the jupyterlab issues, is to create `https://github.com/jupyterlab/benchmarks`.

For the CI run, we still would have the flexibility to run benchmark in main `jupyterlab` repo based on a published npm artifact or in the `benchmarks` repo (with bots...).

items.title: Cannot override ISessionContextDialogs in Notebook widget
items.body:
## Description
When default NotebookWidgetFactory is initialized, sessionDialog option is not passed in ( https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/2.2.x/packages/notebook-extension/src/index.ts#L515 ).
Because of that `defaultToolbarFactory` will use default `sessionContextDialogs` ( https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/2.2.x/packages/notebook/src/widgetfactory.ts#L45 )

## Reproduce

1. Disable `@jupyterlab/apputils-extension:sessionDialogs` plugin
2. Write a custom provider for `ISessionContextDialogs`
3. Configure JupiterLab to use your new provider
3. Launch JupiterLab and open a notebook
4. Click on `kernelName` toolbar button to bring up kernel selection dialog
5. [issue] The kernel selection dialog is the same as default implementation

## Expected behavior

Expect the new `ISessionContextDialogs` provider be used in creating kernel selection dialog 

## Context

<!--Complete the following for context, and add any other relevant context-->

- Operating System and version: Windows 10
- Browser and version: Chrome 84.0.4147.105 
- JupyterLab version: 2.2

items.title: Feature Requeat: Open notebooks from Markdown
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Thanks for thinking of a way to improve JupyterLab. If this solves a problem for you, then it probably solves that problem for lots of people! So the whole community will benefit from this request.


Before creating a new feature request please search the issues for relevant feature requests.
-->

### Problem

<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of what problem this feature will solve. For example:

* I'm always frustrated when [...] because [...]
* I would like it if [...] happened when I [...] because [...]
-->

Given a markdown file of links, I would like to:

- Open the markdown file (rendered)
- Click on a link to a notebook
- Open the notebook

Right now, I think such links attempt to download the notebook rather than open them.

### Proposed Solution

<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of a way to accomplish what you want. For example:

* Add an option so that when [...]  [...] will happen
 -->

Main idea
- Render markdown previews in Jupyterlab so that links to notebook files open them as rendered notebooks (not as a raw file, or attempt to download the file)



### Additional context

<!-- Add any other context or screenshots about the feature request here. You can also include links to examples of other programs that have something similar to your request. For example:

* Another project [...] solved this by [...]
-->

I use this functionality all the time with an older Anaconda/Notebook setup.

- Start Anaconda from a Jupyter Notebook icon
- The terminal opens and runs the server in the background
- Open a browser
- Click on a bookmark to my markdown file of links
- The file renders nicely in the browser
- Click on a link to a notebook
- The notebook opens in the browser

Details

Here is a working example from an existing jupyter setup:

A - Markdown file of relative paths to notebooks
![a](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10778668/89541814-d67c6c00-d7cc-11ea-80b7-28eb042f0ee6.png)

B - Rendered markdown file (bookmarked to access quickly)
![b](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10778668/89541306-34f51a80-d7cc-11ea-8d0a-8f967841f3ce.png)

C - Rendered notebook opened from the link
![c](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10778668/89541314-37577480-d7cc-11ea-9ffc-87bb820e5a1f.png)


- The address of the mentioned bookmark that I used looks like this:
`http://localhost:8888/nbextensions/nbextensions_configurator/rendermd/tree/markdown_file_w_links.md`

This feature helps me organize 100s of notebooks into custom groups.

items.title: Jupyterlab not starting after upgrade to > 2.
items.body:
<!--

-->

## Description

when I upgrade to any version > 2. the JupyterLab notebook does not start.
Until 1.2.16 it worked fine, I am using `jupyter-labhub` within `Jupyterhub`. 

This is error I see:

```
from jupyterlab.labhubapp import main
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'jupyterlab.labhubapp'
```

## Context

<!--Complete the following for context, and add any other relevant context-->

- Jupyterhub 1.1.0:
- JupyterLab version: 2.2.2 (I tried all 2.xxx)

items.title: Update usages of `open_browser`
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description
Following #7416, we need to update usages of [`open_browser`](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/499ea4669fb35deeab027ecc727f4900f0f550ae/jupyterlab/browser_check.py#L163) to use the new pattern:

```
     serverapp_config = {
            "open_browser": False
        }
```

items.title: Configurable toggle comment key.
items.body: The same functionality as https://jupyter-contrib-nbextensions.readthedocs.io/en/latest/nbextensions/comment-uncomment/readme.html

items.title: Missing workspacesUrl in index HTML for PageConfig?
items.body:
Hi, While working working on [JupyterLab as Server Extension](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/7416), the workspace clone is broken. It turns out that workspacesUrl is no more generated

  <script id="jupyter-config-data" type="application/json">
..., "treeUrl": "/lab/tree", "userSettingsDir": "/Users/echar4/.jupyter/lab/user-settings", "workspacesApiUrl": "/lab/api/workspaces", "workspacesDir": "/Users/echar4/.jupyter/lab/workspaces", "workspacesUrl": "/lab/workspaces", "wsUrl": ""}...
  </script>

I have looked in the current master, but can not find where this key/value is generated.

If I set `workspaces: '/lab/workspaces',` in `lab.ts`, the workspace cloning works fine.

items.title: Jupyter notebook in aws sagemaker studio

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
Hi,
when I try to change my instance type from medium to any other large instance, I get this error. Please help, thanks!

> `Failed to change to instance ml.m5.12xlargeAn error occurred (ResourceLimitExceeded) when calling the CreateApp operation: The account-level service limit 'KernelGateway Apps running on ml.m5.12xlarge instance' is 0 Apps, with current utilization of 0 Apps and a request delta of 1 Apps. Please contact AWS support to request an increase for this limit.`

items.title: [2.2.x] `import time` missing in `browser_check`
items.body:
The package `time` is not imported in `browser_check` on branch `2.2.x`.

So the following statement raises an error:
https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/b5024e97f8b9160dd9cef70d619027fbf7a47aa7/jupyterlab/browser_check.py#L134

> Note: the exception is silenced as it happens after the test succeeds. See for example: https://travis-ci.org/github/jupyterlab/jupyterlab-git/jobs/714050835#L1169

items.title: a syntax error in the doc
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->
There is a syntax error in typescript code in the docs/source/developer/extension_points.rst


## Reproduce

original code:
```
palette.addItem({
  command: commandID,
  category: 'my-category'
  args: {}
});
```


<!--Describe how you diagnosed the issue. See the guidelines at
 https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html -->

## Expected behavior

```
palette.addItem({
  command: commandID,
  category: 'my-category',
  args: {}
});
```

## Context

- JupyterLab version: latest master branch

items.title: VegaLite not working in master
items.body:
## Description

When you click on a `.vl` file to render it with VegaLite, I see a JS loading issue (will post screenshot).

## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->

Double click on any `.vl` VegaLite file in the file browser.

## Expected behavior

The visualization will render in a new panel.

items.title: Starting Kernel Error  (same as #5424)
items.body:
## Description
I re-installed miniconda and encounter the same issue as gboing and others reported in Issue 5424.
When I run the kernel spec, solution in that issue, I get the same json as reported in that issue.  Yet, I still get the same dead kernel in my env.

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->

items.title: Browser check is not failing when it should
items.body: I noticed while working on https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab-module-federation/pull/22 that despite the chrome test failing, the job was succeeding.  Pinning to 2.1.5 allowed the job to properly [fail](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab-module-federation/pull/22/commits/903e26076e06f74c6fb80b1307dc715a373878dc).

items.title: Bring back the labhub entry point
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description
We previously had this interface in 1.0.  We removed it in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/7724.  However, based on the feedback from https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/8356 and @athornton on [gitter](https://gitter.im/jupyterlab/jupyterlab?at=5f171e82a15ff42fa8e1da20), we need to bring this back in order to pass settings to the lab app.

items.title: Minimized build fails with terser error
items.body:
Hi, I am using three.js in a jupyter lab extension.
When I run a production build 

`jupyter lab build --dev-build=False`

I get an error from terser and the build fails. It is complaining about trailing commas in  a function call. Apparently (https://github.com/terser/terser/issues/412) this could be fixed here:

https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/f0153e0258b32674c9aec106383ddf7b618cebab/dev_mode/webpack.prod.minimize.config.js#L15

with the default ecma setting which is 8.

items.title: Question: Help updating to JLab2? labextension widget fails to load after updating
items.body:
## Description
Updating 1.1.4 to 2.1.4

As far as I can tell, the main changes for getting the old code to work with jlab2 were some modules being refactored from the core jupyterlab package to their own packages and replacing `phosphor` with `lumino`.  

Applying those changes worked for all except one.  
I still get the `<extension-name> has activated` message in the console, which means the activate function is running, but the menu items to attach/update the widget don't show up. After playing around some more, I think it's an issue with creating/attaching a custom widget, which I haven't changed at all.  Could the specs for a jlab widget have changed in this update?

## Reproduce
Not sure how to give clear reproduction steps: I took a extension developed for 1.1.4, did the aforementioned changes, and did a dev install of the extension.  It works when running JupyterLab locally on my Mac, but not when inside a docker container.

Now I see 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11476825/87481804-f319ef80-c5e4-11ea-9d60-70f1d1abcc11.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11476825/87481279-e1841800-c5e3-11ea-81cd-5e30054c14bc.png)

items.title: Magic Function not working in Jupyter lab with debugger
items.body:
I followed this instruction to install the debugger ( Windows 10, 16GB HDD with Nvidia):

https://github.com/jupyterlab/debugger

Then I tried to run magic function ( Using dark mode):

import numpy as np
from numpy.random import randint

 #A function to simulate one million dice throws.

def one_million_dice():
    return randint(low=1, high=7, size=1000000)

# New Line

%%time
throws = one_million_dice()
mean = np.mean(throws)

I get an error: 

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
SyntaxError                               Traceback (most recent call last)
File C:\Users\chhapoli\Anaconda3\envs\jupyterlab-debugger\lib\ast.py, in parse:
Line 35:    return compile(source, filename, mode, PyCF_ONLY_AST)

SyntaxError: invalid syntax (<string>, line 1)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Question1: How to see traceback in Jupyter Lab

Question2: How to fix it?

Question 3: Crashes when I opens up big csv file. ( 1.018 GB)

```
https://jupyter.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributor/content-contributor.html: 404: Not Found
```

example: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/runs/860658977

items.title: Unusable load times when opening notebooks with many cells

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
## Description

Opening a notebook with 2k cells takes ~20 minutes on my machine. Aside from the time taken, this also locks up the webpage as its blocking. It seems reasonable to question if that is even a valid notebook size, but it has come up in practice which hints it's not contrived. In this case, it was the result of writing a lot of code in a single notebook, but rendering almost every intermediate step. Many python modules are much greater than 2k LOC.

## Reproduce

Create a notebook:
```
import nbformat
import json

cells = []
for i in range(2000):
    cells.append(nbformat.v4.new_code_cell(source='print({})'.format(i)))

nb = nbformat.v4.new_notebook(cells=cells, metadata={'language': 'python',})

with open('large-notebook.ipynb', 'w') as f:
    f.write(json.dumps(nb, indent=4))
```

Now try to open `large-notebook.ipynb`. To time it, before you open the notebook, run this in dev tools `setInterval(() => console.log('now'), 5000)`. The large notebook blocked for ~20 minutes for me. Quick debugging shows it's mostly code-mirror trying to create cells. If you merge all the code into one cell, you'll see it opens slowly, but not in an unusable amount of time.

## Expected behavior

1. A notebook loading never blocks other interactions for too long
2. Large notebooks are loaded faster or in parts or ...

## Context

<!--Complete the following for context, and add any other relevant context-->

- Operating System and version: `2.1.2`
- Browser and version: Chrome
- JupyterLab version: Windows

items.title: Provide a UI for selecting localization language of the interface
items.body:
So with the work on [localization](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/3965) I added a top level menu for displaying the installed language-packs on the server:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3627835/86969910-23204900-c134-11ea-9f08-520d2418ef4e.png)

This was for demo purposes, cause there probably should be a different way of setting the interface language.

Some examples of how VSCode does it, via de omni thinguie...

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3627835/86970012-4c40d980-c134-11ea-8064-701c1418600b.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3627835/86970019-4fd46080-c134-11ea-9101-32f9a9315c1b.png)


And selecting the install additional languages opens the extension manager with those type of available package
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3627835/86970046-5f53a980-c134-11ea-8f18-d0123859bda5.png)


@isabela-pf @tgeorgeux any ideas suggestions and thoughts on what could be the best way to expose this?

Thanks!

items.title: missing buffer polyfill on master
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

Very much like https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/8657 I am seeing a build failure when trying to install from master branch (abc0dd4255a037af37828122bd2e199857fd64db) I am seeing failures like

```
  ModuleNotFoundError: Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'buffer' in '/tmp/pip-req-build-cjkgmzab/jupyterlab/staging/node_modules/htmlparser2/lib'

  BREAKING CHANGE: webpack < 5 used to include polyfills for node.js core modules by default.
  This is no longer the case. Verify if you need these module and configure a polyfill for it.

  If you want to include a polyfill, you need to install 'buffer'.
  If you don't want to include a polyfill, you can use an empty module like this:
  	resolve.alias: { "buffer": false }
```

This seems to have been broken by 9499eb52f8c9e3d63bb73c9af74ec8d6088307a2

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->

```
git clean -xfd
```

items.title: Build error in master from Webpack 5
items.body:
## Description
After an attempt to release 3.0a1, the resulting CI build is showing this error:

```
 ModuleNotFoundError: Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'url' in 'C:\Users\RUNNER~1\AppData\Local\Temp\tmp3i4nkjrs\staging\node_modules\sanitize-html\dist'

BREAKING CHANGE: webpack < 5 used to include polyfills for node.js core modules by default.
This is no longer the case. Verify if you need these module and configure a polyfill for it.

If you want to include a polyfill, you need to install 'url'.
If you don't want to include a polyfill, you can use an empty module like this:
	resolve.alias: { "url": false }
```

We missed it because the usage test timeout masked the error that we would have caught in `browser_check`.

items.title: Refreshing the file without closing and reopening its respective widget?
items.body:
I am trying to make a JupyterLab extension that will pull from a Git repo and show the changes on JupyterLab. I currently have all the Git functionality working, but I'm having issues trying to make the changes show for files that are already opened. For example if I have `hi.txt` opened in JupyterLab, but I receive changes from a Git pull, the changes will not show on the file editor unless I close it and reopen it. 

I have tried playing around with the `DocumentManager` class (specifically the `open()` function), but it seems that the same context for the `DocumentWidget` is used. So even if I am able to open up new tabs of the same file, the same context for the already opened file is used, and therefore no changes are being shown in the new tabs. This means that I need to make sure the existing context is disposed before I can reopen a new context. 

Since I would like be able to use the same widget (so from the user perspective the changes show up on the same file editor without some weird flashing of the file editor closing and reopening), I thought that replacing the context might work, but since most useful functions relating to contexts are private (including `_createContext`), I don't know if this is a viable option anymore.

TLDR: Does anyone know of a good way to refresh the contents in the file editor without having to close and reopen the entire widget?

items.title: Export with nbconvert --no-input
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Thanks for thinking of a way to improve JupyterLab. If this solves a problem for you, then it probably solves that problem for lots of people! So the whole community will benefit from this request.


Before creating a new feature request please search the issues for relevant feature requests.
-->

### Problem
I am trying to export a notebook without code cells and prompts. On the CLI I can achieve this with --no-input or with a custom template --template. In #5015 the exporters are loaded automatically, but I am not sure how to change the default behavor or add it as an option.
<!-- Provide a clear and concise description of what problem this feature will solve. For example:

* I'm always frustrated when [...] because [...]
* I would like it if [...] happened when I [...] because [...]
-->

### Proposed Solution
I wouldn't mind changing the default for nbconvert in jupyterlab or nbconvert to always use --no-input. Clear instructions if this is possible would be a solution to me. Adding the option to eg export HTML with --no-input in the jupyterlab menu in addition to what is there would be preferable. Another solution would be to use my own nbconvert template in jupyterlab, where I have one that already excludes code cells and prompts. If this is already possible some user config documentation would be nice.

### Additional context
From what I have gathered, one would add in jupyter_nbconvert_config.py the lines
```
c.TemplateExporter.exclude_output_prompt = True
c.TemplateExporter.exclude_input = True
```
This does not seem to work, nor if I add them to jupyter_notebook_config.py instead. I have also tried the json equivalent config files, but without clear documentation on what I should do there.

items.title: Is @jupyterlab/services 5.2.0 backward incompatible with 5.1.x?
items.body:
### Update
The root cause of this bug appears to be that the new 5.2.x line of `@jupyterlab/services` adds a new `Status` in `src/kernel/messages.ts` (`terminating`): https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/master/packages/services/src/kernel/messages.ts#L538

This status did  not exist in earlier versions so it creates a breaking change. We should likely bump the version of `@jupyterlab/services` to 6.0, cc: @saulshanabrook 

### Original issue
We are working on an extension that is built to target JupyterLab 2. Sometime in the recent past, even though the published files in the pip package ask for `"@jupyterlab/services": "^5.1.0"` what is happening is that they are picking up `@jupyterlab/services` version `5.2.0-alpha.2`

Has anyone encountered this? Is there a mistake in what we published or something else? Here is the pull request that demonstrates the issue. It was passing two weeks ago but after re-running it, it fails now. I think is has something to do with the publication of that alpha version of `@jupyterlab/services` five days ago: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@jupyterlab/services/v/5.2.0-alpha.2

Here is a pull request the demonstrates the error in the test failures: https://github.com/jupyterlab/debugger/pull/459

## Description
When trying to build an extension that was building two weeks ago (without any modification), today we get errors like these:
```
$ tsc --build tsconfig.test.json
test/debugger.spec.ts(81,5): error TS2322: Type 'import("/home/runner/work/debugger/debugger/node_modules/@jupyterlab/codemirror/node_modules/@jupyterlab/services/lib/session/session").ISessionConnection' is not assignable to type 'import("/home/runner/work/debugger/debugger/node_modules/@jupyterlab/services/lib/session/session").ISessionConnection'.
  Types of property 'kernelChanged' are incompatible.
```

cc: @KrzysztofSikoraCodete @jtpio

items.title: Contributing Guide Link is Out of Sync
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description
The link in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md should point to https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developer/contributing.html, not https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/stable/developer/contributing.html.  

Right now the content that was in `CONTRIBUTING.md` is not yet in stable, so a lot of the docs are effectively missing.

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->


<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->
## Reproduction
1. Click the Read the Docs link in https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
2. Switch to the latest version in the lower left
3.  Note how many more sections there are in the contributing guide.

items.title: PDFLaTeX from menu does not work, while working in CLI
items.body:
## Description It is not really a bug, though we could expect that the same environment could be used in both cases, described below. We are providing to people of our lab a JupyterLab interface. We wanted to provide a LaTeX environment, allowing LaTeX and PDF exports. While PDF export from the CLI within a notebook will work [1], trying to do it from the menu, i.e. `File ->Export Notebook As ->Export Notebook to PDF`, will not! [1]: issuing, from a cell, or in a terminal, here from a cell of the notebook `! jupyter nbconvert --to pdf notebook.ipynb ` It seems that from the menu, the environment is not the user's environment, but the system's one (thus, in our case, xelatex is not found). Since we are providing custom kernels [2], with specific environments, we would like that ones to be used. That would explain why conversion works from the notebook (using a custom environment, which includes LaTeX), using the `nbconvert` CLI, though it won't from the menu. Please not that the LaTeX environment is well defined in the notebook (see the specific texlive installation). [2] custom kernels are made following that documentation : [https://jupyter-client.readthedocs.io/en/stable/kernels.html](https://jupyter-client.readthedocs.io/en/stable/kernels.html) but instead of refering to a Python executable, we refer to a script that set up a whole environment. ## Expected behavior Is there a way to ensure that the environment used in the menu to export a notebook to PDF is the one set up by the custom kernel? ## Context - Operating System and version: CentOS 7.6.1810 (core) - JupyterLab version: 1.2.5 The JupyterLab is running within a Docker container in a cloud environment. All browsers tested exhibit this behaviour.
Troubleshoot Output

items.title: Does the use-sys-dir work?
items.body:
Does the `--use-sys-dir` flag work?

## Description
 I'm trying to run JupyterLab from a specified application directory `--app-dir=./foo` and to *not* use the system directory's extensions with `--use-sys-dir=False` and I'm getting on JupyterLab 2.x and also JupyterLab 1.x:

```
[C 13:39:29.634 LabApp] Bad config encountered during initialization:
[C 13:39:29.634 LabApp] Invalid argument: '--use-sys-dir=False'
```

## Reproduce
```
jupyter lab --app-dir=./foo --use-sys-dir=False
```
## Expected behavior
This flag should be accepted as valid configuration and ignore the system directory.

## Context

cf. https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/master/jupyterlab/commands.py#L314-L317

- Operating System and version: macOS and also Linux
- Browser and version: N/A
- JupyterLab version: 1.x and 2.x

items.title: API Docs: logconsole and logconsole-extension, file not found.
items.body:
<!--
Welcome! Before creating a new issue:
* Search for relevant issues
* Follow the issue reporting guidelines:
https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html
-->

## Description

<!--Describe the bug clearly and concisely. Include screenshots if possible-->
When trying to access the API docs pages of logconsole and logconsole-extension it says "404
File not found".

## Reproduce

<!--Describe step-by-step instructions to reproduce the behavior-->
You can access through API Docs main page:
[https://jupyterlab.github.io/jupyterlab/index.html](https://jupyterlab.github.io/jupyterlab/index.html)
or through these URLs:
[https://jupyterlab.github.io/jupyterlab/index.html](https://jupyterlab.github.io/jupyterlab/logconsole/index.html)
[https://jupyterlab.github.io/jupyterlab/index.html](https://jupyterlab.github.io/jupyterlab/logconsole-extension/index.html)

<!--Describe how you diagnosed the issue. See the guidelines at
 https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/latest/getting_started/issue.html -->

## Expected behavior

<!--Describe what you expected to happen-->

items.title: 2.2 Release Plans
items.body:
We were originally planning on making the next release 3.0, and skipping a minor release. However, we [have decided to push back the 3.0 release](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/8038#issuecomment-645542556) and so it makes sense to do another minor release.

Unfortunately, we have started merging in breaking changes into master. So we need to figure out which PRs that were merged in since the last release should be released under 2.2.

Please make sure any PRs and issues that need to be released in the minor release (which cannot be changes) are added to [that milestone](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/milestone/53?closed=1).

My tentative timeline is:

* Wednesday 6/24: All relevant PRs should be merged, finish moving PRs to correct milestone
* Thursday 6/25: Create git branch for release, cherry pick commits, generate release notes, release first RC
* Thursday 7/2: Release final version (pending any large issues that arise from pre release)

Please comment if you have suggestions for the timeline.

items.title: Pressing Alt+W multiple times doesn't close more than one tab

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
## Description Shortcuts should be designed so that if the same shortcut is pressed/entered multiple times, that particular action should be done those many number of times. However, for the Alt+W shortcut to close a tab, however number of times I press it, it only closes one tab ## Reproduce 1. Start Jupyter Lab 2. Open a few tabs 3. hold Alt key and press W key multiple times - **Alternate**: press Alt+W release all the keys and repeat it multiple times ## Expected behavior On entering shortcuts _n_ number of times, _n_ tabs (or all of the tabs if number of tabs is < _n_) should be closed ## Context - Operating System and version: Ubuntu 20.04 LTS - Browser and version: Firefox 77.0.1 (64-bit) / Chrome Version 83.0.4103.97 (Official Build) (64-bit) - JupyterLab version: Version 2.1.4

items.title: Markdown cell FileBrowser drag-and-drop attach

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
### Reproduce

Drag an image file from the JupyterLab FileBrowser to a notebook Markdown code cell. It's not droppable, cannot be attached to the Markdown code cell.

### Expected behavior

In JupyterLab 1.2, one could drag an image from the JupyterLab FileBrowser to attach to a Markdown cell. https://jupyterlab.readthedocs.io/en/stable/getting_started/changelog.html#id5 One could not drag an image from the OS (Gnome shell) to attach to a Markdown cell. 

After JupyterLab 2.0, one can drag an image from the OS (Gnome shell) to attach to a Markdown cell. One cannot drag an image from the JupyterLab FileBrowser to attach to a Markdown cell.

So in JupyterLab 2.0, we lost the ability to drag an image from the JupyterLab FileBrowser to attach to a Markdown cell. It would be nice to get that ability back.

### Context

No errors are produced in the Javascript console, or in any other place I can see. The drop-attach operation from FileBrowser to Markdown cell just fails silently.

items.title: Output prompt and output content baselines not aligned
items.body: ## Description There seems to be much history with output prompt & content and text styling, and this particular issue likely exists because of changes that helped address other issues. That said, the misaligned text baselines of the output prompt and output content jump out at me every time I see it. It is less noticeable in Chrome (macOS) because of the difference between fonts used for the prompts and the output content (#8552), but Safari (macOS) uses the same font for both. It seems like #7832 has **increased** the baseline difference (in Safari, it went from 1px to 2px which made it more noticeable to me). The image below is after #8553 in Chrome since having the same font is important. I have tried to track down the various style parameters that affect this, and have made the following observations: 1. `--jp-cell-prompt-font-family` and `--jp-code-font-family`are inconsistent (see #8552) 2. `--jp-code-line-height` (used in the output prompt) and `.jp-RenderedText pre` line-heights are inconsistent (see #8554) 3. The output prompt (`jp-OutputPrompt`) contains a 5px paddding (`--jp-code-padding`) **plus** a 1px border (`var(--jp-border-width) solid transparent`) while the output content (`jp-OutputArea-output`) has **only** a `padding-top` of 5px (`--jp-code-padding`). Adding these up, even when using the same font (added in #8553), the output content text seems off because (a) it does not have the 1px border and (b) it's line height (2px difference) moves the baseline up 1px. #8555 addresses (b). I'm not sure what the purpose of the border around the prompt is used for, but my guess is that this to be consistent with the input prompt which has it in order to align with the input content which has the border styled as `(var(--jp-border-width) solid var(--jp-cell-editor-active-border-color)` to show when an input cell is active. To be consistent, it seems reasonable to add this to the output content as well. This will align the baselines of the prompt and the content for code-like output. ## Reproduce Execute `s = '[1]: a line of text'` ## Expected behavior Baselines of the output prompt (e.g. `[1]`) and the output (e.g. `'[1]: a line of text'`) are the same. ## Context - Operating System and version: macOS 10.15.5 - Browser and version: Chrome v83 - JupyterLab version: 2.2.0a0

items.title: Add tests to ToC
items.body: ToC currently doesn't have any tests. Referenced in #8546.

items.title: Update ToC icon usage to LabIcon
items.body: Currently the ToC package uses icons located in `packages/toc/style/img`, but these icons should be moved to `ui-components` and imported to ToC using LabIcon. Referenced in #8546.

items.title: Output line height does not match input code line height
items.body: ## Description The issue raised in #7760 regarded gaps between ansi color blocks. It was originally fixed by changing the line-height to `normal` for content in `jp-RenderedText pre`. This had the side effect of changing the line heights of the output. ## Reproduce A list demonstrates the difference between the overall height of the input and of the output: ``` [123456789, 123456790, 123456791, 123456792, 123456793, 123456794, 123456795, 123456796, 123456797, 123456798] ``` ## Expected behavior The input and output line heights are the same for code-like text ## Context - Operating System and version: macOS 10.15.5 - Browser and version: Chrome v83 - JupyterLab version: 2.2.0a0

items.title: Cell Prompt and Code Fonts are Inconsistent
items.body: ## Description I've noticed that the font used in the cell prompt versus that used in other code-like contexts does not match. I've tracked this down to #5123 which modified `--jp-code-font-family` but left `--jp-cell-prompt-font-family` unchanged. Note that both were the same `Source Code Pro, monospace` string before that change so it seems reasonable to expect that they were intended to be the same font. This was also noted in [#5547](https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/pull/5547#issuecomment-434008713). ## Reproduce This is most visible in Chrome (macOS) which (at least for my configuration) defaults `monospace` to `Courier`. Safari (macOS) uses the same font for both. ## Expected behavior The font-family for the cell prompt and the cell content should be the same. ## Context - Operating System and version: macOS 10.15.5 - Browser and version: Chrome v83 - JupyterLab version: 2.2.0a0

items.title: Issues in extensions whitelist/blacklist documentation
items.body:
Hi,

There seems to be some mistakes in the whitelist/blacklist documentation for the extension manager.

1. https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/master/docs/source/user/extensions.rst#listings

> Only one mode at a time is allowed. If you or your server administrator configures both black and white listings, the extension manager will be disabled.

However, it seems that enabling both blacklist and whitelist actually prevents the server from starting https://github.com/datalayer-contrib/jupyterlab-server/blob/master/jupyterlab_server/handlers.py#L308-L311.


2. https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/master/docs/source/user/extensions.rst#listing-configuration

It might be useful to better emphasize that `blacklist_uris` (resp `whitelist_uris`) expects a URI to a `blacklist` file as shown below. At first, I was actually thinking this was a comma-separated list of extensions (or URIs of extensions), which was obviously not working.

Thanks!
Best

items.title: Responding bash prompt inside a cell output

milestone.title: Reference
milestone.description: This milestone is for issues that have no further action planned, but which are useful reference.

items.body:
### Problem
As much as I know, there is no such feature in jupyterlab to answer prompts like 'yes/no questions' or other prompts in jupyterlab. However, the Google Colab version of the jupyterlab has this built-in feature.

### Proposed Solution
The best thing is to use Colab code, if it is opensource, to add this feature because Colab is very similar to jupyterlab.

### Additional context

Using bash tools is a large part of my bioinformatics pipelines. I also use Python and R along with bash. Recently, I came across a plugin for Jupiter, Script of scripts (SoS) which makes it possible to run bash, Python, R, and other kernels in the same notebook which is really awesome. Having the possibility of answering bash prompts would be very helpful for my work. I know it is possible to use printf <prompt_answer> and pipe it to the next command. However, being able to answer prompts instantaneously is much better.

items.title: Close Tab closes incorrect tab if tabs have same title
items.body:
## Description Using the Close Tab from the context menu on a different tab will close the current tab if the two tabs have the same title. ![close-tab](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10111092/83555319-19c01300-a4dc-11ea-90e2-1c2bc4ca5523.gif) I encountered this with diffs in the `jupyterlab-git` extension but it happens for any files with the same name, including markdown files and their previews: ![close-tab-2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10111092/83555190-e8dfde00-a4db-11ea-88e5-cc74e3271f86.gif) I think that this is distinct from https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/issues/6008#issuecomment-466085325 as `Close All Other Tabs` now works as expected no matter what widget is currently focused. ![close-all-works](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/10111092/83555475-568c0a00-a4dc-11ea-8835-d2758ff90bd4.gif) ## Reproduce 1. Open two tabs with the same name 2. Focus one of the tabs 3. Right click the other tab and select Close Tab 4. Focused tab will be closed ## Expected behavior The tab I right clicked on would be closed. My guess is that the widget id needs to be used somehow here: https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/e7317f21b48183423e375dc266476a4289eb0fa3/packages/application-extension/src/index.tsx#L605-L614 compare to the id checking in Close All Other Tabs https://github.com/jupyterlab/jupyterlab/blob/e7317f21b48183423e375dc266476a4289eb0fa3/packages/application-extension/src/index.tsx#L628-L646 ## Context - Operating System and version: PopOS 20.04 - Browser and version: Firefox 75 - JupyterLab version: 2.1.3

items.title: API for Sending Data to Jupyter Console from Emacs other editors
items.body:
Presently most of the Emacs Jupyter Plugin Environment connects to ipython server and use those ipython server API to send lines or buffer which then executes the code. 

I want to actually send a line/buffer to Jupyter Console(Frontend) directly where it would then get executed. 

I wanted to ask how to make this possible, is there a API system associated with Console/FrontEnd which can be used to send data to the frontend for eg creating a new cell, sending line, and executing a cell.

Thanks for your help
